options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course basically teaches you a lot about the utility maximizing choices that consumers and firms make, and what happens when you put consumers and firms together to get a model of an equilibrium. The course then adds a model with various periods, and finally with money, and looks at the changes with rigid and non rigid prices. The course also teaches about growth theory (solo model and some endogenous human capital  growth theory). The main skills you take away from this class are solving pretty complex algebra models and also some intuition abut how different choices you make change with different parameters.
How to model to the economy and how to use work with those models mathematically.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think a weakness of the course is that the material was never tied together in an overarching way - it felt as if a lot of what we did was dive down in the details of a model, and sometimes never followed through on the big picture of it - for example,e we never really assessed what our models of sticky / non sticky prices really said about what we should believe causes business cycles.

Strengths: Class was almost entirely self-contained (i.e. if you're good enough at math, you can probably take it without intro econ, but it will be tough). Clear teaching. PSets were useful. Weaknesses: textbook wasn't very helpful, but also not very necessary.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course used the pretty standard zoom lectures and recordings.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think if you are considering this course vs Econ 122, this course is not that much more difficult; I never took Econ 122, but this course was very manageable, with the advantage of having small numbers and probably a faster pace.
If you like economics, yes! Econ core classes can be dry, but this is my favorite I've taken so far. It is difficult but worthwhile.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I also watched the lecture recorded.
